questions.question: Match the following with their correct terms. 1 Exon i Non-coding region 2 Intron ii One of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome 3 Locus iii Coding region 4 Allele iv Location of a gene on the chromosome
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1-iii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-ii Explanation: Exon : An exon is a coding region of a gene that contains the genetic information necessary for producing a functional protein. Intron : An intron is a non-coding region of a gene that intervenes between exons. During gene expression, introns are removed from the pre-mRNA molecule through splicing, which allows exons to be joined together to form the final mRNA transcript before translation into a protein. Locus : A locus refers to the specific location of a gene or DNA sequence on a chromosome. Allele : An allele is one of the alternate forms of a single gene occupying a given position in a chromosome , which can lead to different traits or characteristics. Alleles can be dominant or recessive. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 459

questions.question: A 25-year-old male from a tribal area of Madhya Pradesh presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. On examination, he appears pale, and jaundice is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin levels and increased reticulocyte count. The peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle-shaped erythrocytes. What is the most likely molecular mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Missense mutation Explanation: The clinical presentation of a tribal male with the above-mentioned clinical features and sickle-shaped RBCs in the peripheral smear suggests sickle cell disease. A missense mutation (type of point mutation) is the underlying mechanism in the pathogenesis of this disease. Point mutation: A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. Types: Missense mutation It can be: Sickle cell anaemia. This point mutation involves substituting adenine for thymine at the sixth codon of the β -globin gene (GAG to GTG) , replacing glutamic acid with valine in the β -globin chain of haemoglobin. This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS) . Nonsense mutation (Option D) Change of an amino acid to a chain terminator or stop codon. (UAA, UGA, UAG) Example: Beta thalassemia This change leads to premature termination of β -globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. Chromosomal translocation (Option A) involves the exchange of genetic material between non-homologous chromosomes. E.g. Chronic myeloid leukemia- t(9;22). A frameshift mutation (Option C) is a type of genetic mutation that results from the insertion or deletion of nucleotides in a DNA sequence, causing a shift in the reading frame during translation. E.g., Cystic fibrosis: A three-base deletion in the common cystic fibrosis (CF) allele results in the synthesis of a protein that lacks amino acid 508 (phenylalanine). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Pages 142,143

questions.question: A couple visits a genetics counselor due to concerns about their baby's blood type. The father has blood type A (genotype I A I A ), and the mother has blood type B (genotype I B I B ). The counselor explains that blood type is determined by codominant alleles, where both alleles contribute equally to the phenotype in the heterozygous condition. Which of the following best describes codominance?

options.A: One allele completely masks the expression of the other allele
options.B: The phenotype of the heterozygote is intermediate between the phenotypes of the homozygotes
options.C: Only one allele is expressed, while the other remains silent
options.D: Both alleles contribute to the phenotype equally in the heterozygous condition

questions.explanation: Correct answer : D) Both alleles contribute to the phenotype equally in the heterozygous condition are equally expressed . Examples: ABO blood group system In the ABO blood group system, the I A and I B alleles are codominant in producing the AB blood group phenotype, in which both A and B-type antigens are produced. The genes responsible for the ABO blood group are located in chromosome 9. The presence of both I A and I B causes the expression of both , forming the AB blood group. Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Textbook of Anatomy, Volume 3, 6th edition, Pages 481-484

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of tall stature, long limbs, and joint hypermobility. Upon further examination, he also exhibits features such as a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers), and aortic root dilation. His father has a similar appearance. Which of the following statements is true regarding the inheritance pattern seen in this condition? inactive protein.

options.A: Males are more commonly affected than females.
options.B: Most mutations lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or
options.D: The least common mode of inheritance

questions.explanation: dysfunctional or inactive protein. Correct answer: B) Most mutations lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or inactive protein. Explanation : The given clinical scenario of a male with tall stature , long limbs , joint hypermobility , arachnodactyly , aortic root dilatation , and similar features in his father suggests Marfan’s syndrome , an autosomal dominant condition. The true statement regarding autosomal dominant inheritance is that most proteins lead to reduced production of a gene product or give rise to a dysfunctional or inactive protein. Autosomal dominant inheritance: Autosomal dominant disorders are manifested in the heterozygous state, so at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. It is the most common mode of inheritance. (Option D) Both males and females are affected, and both can transmit the condition. (Option A) They are characterized by: With every autosomal dominant disorder, some proportion of patients do not have affected parents. Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity: Some individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal. This is referred to as incomplete penetrance . (Option C) If a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals, the phenomenon is called variable expressivity. In many conditions the age at onset is delayed; symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood. Pedigree chart: A vertical pattern in the pedigree chart: Individuals of each generation are affected (parent and children). Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing on the deleterious gene to the offspring. Some examples of autosomal dominant disorders:

questions.question: A 6-month-old male infant presents to the pediatric clinic with failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and hepatosplenomegaly. Upon further examination, the infant also displays signs of skeletal abnormalities including bowed legs and frontal bossing. Lab investigations reveal pancytopenia with markedly decreased platelet count. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Gaucher disease. What is the pattern of inheritance and underlying genetic defect leading to this disorder?

options.A: Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene
options.B: X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene
options.C: Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene
options.D: Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Autosomal Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene Explanation : Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase - GBA1 gene. Three clinical subtypes of Gaucher disease have been distinguished: Type I: Chronic non-neuronopathic form. Type II: Acute neuronopathic form, also known as infantile acute cerebral pattern. Type III: Intermediate between types I and II. MORPHOLOGY: In Gaucher disease, glucocerebrosides accumulate massively within phagocytic cells throughout the body, forming distended cells known as Gaucher cells. These cells, found in various organs including the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lungs, exhibit a fibrillar cytoplasm resembling crumpled tissue paper. They stain intensely positive with periodic acid–Schiff staining. Wright stain - Crumpled tissue paper Hematoxylin and eosin stain Other Diseases with Autosomal Recessive inheritance patterns: DISORDERS (Pasta Fried Chawal/ Big Fax) P - Phenylketonuria A - Alkaptonuria S - Sickle Cell Anemia Ta - Thalassemia Fried - Friedreich's Ataxia C - Cystic Fibrosis H - Hemophilia C, Homocystinuria, Hemochromatosis A - Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency W - Wilson Disease A - Albinism, Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia L - Lysosomal Storage Disease, Glycogen Storage Disease Big -Bloom Syndrome Fa - Fanconi Anemia, Ataxia Telangiectasia X - Xeroderma Pigmentosum (Big FAX) is also known as DNA repair defects Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the CFTR Gene (Option A): Cystic fibrosis (CF) is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. (chromosome 7) X-linked Recessive Inheritance, Mutation in the GBA Gene (Option B): Gaucher disease is not associated with X-linked inheritance; instead, it follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Autosomal Dominant Inheritance, Mutation in the HEXA Gene (Option C) Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HEXA gene, resulting in deficient activity of the enzyme β -hexosaminidase A There are two isoenzymes of β -hexosaminidase: Hex A, consisting of two subunits, α and β , and Hex B, a homodimer of β -subunits. Tay-Sachs disease, the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis, results from mutations in the α -subunit locus on chromosome 15 that cause a severe deficiency of hexosaminidase A Features of Tay Sachs disease: Onion skin appearance Cherry red spot

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, and hypotonia. The infant has a cherry-red spot on the macula and exhibits poor startle reflexes on physical examination. Further evaluation reveals foam cells in the bone marrow. What is the diagnosis and associated enzyme deficiency?

options.A: Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase
options.B: Diagnosis: Tay-Sachs disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Hexosaminidase A
options.C: Diagnosis: Gaucher disease, Enzyme Deficiency: Glucocerebrosidase
options.D: Diagnosis: Metachromatic leukodystrophy, Enzyme Deficiency: Arylsulfatase A

questions.explanation: sphingomyelinase Correct answer: A) Diagnosis: Niemann-Pick disease type A, Enzyme Deficiency: Acid sphingomyelinase Explanation : Niemann-Pick disease types A and B are related disorders characterized by lysosomal accumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase. Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life. In contrast, patients with type B disease have organomegaly but generally no central nervous system involvement. Patients usually survive into adulthood. Affected cells become enlarged, due to the distention of lysosomes with sphingomyelin and cholesterol, imparting foaminess to the cytoplasm. Image : Niemann-Pick disease in the liver. The hepatocytes and Kupffer cells have a foamy, vacuolated appearance due to the deposition of lipids. Electron microscopy confirms that the vacuoles are engorged secondary lysosomes called zebra bodies . Image : Zebra bodies Lysosomal Storage Disorders Enzyme Accumulated Substrate Clinical Features Tay-Sachs Disease Hexosaminidase A ( α -subunit). GM2 gangliosides. Motor and mental decline, muscular flaccidity. Blindness, dementia, and macular cherry-red spot. Fatal by 2-3 years of age. Niemann-Pick Disease Sphingomyelinase Sphingomyelin. Type A: Severe neurological damage, wasting, visceral sphingomyelin accumulation; death in 3 years. Type B: Organomegaly without CNS involvement; survival into adulthood. Niemann-Pick Disease Type C Nonenzymatic lipid transport (NPC1, NPC2 proteins). Cholesterol, gangliosides. Variable presentations: hydrops fetalis, neonatal hepatitis. Chronic form: ataxia, dystonia, psychomotor regression, vertical gaze palsy. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) Various enzymes degrading mucopolysaccharides. Dermatan, heparan, keratan, and chondroitin sulfates. Coarse facial features, corneal clouding, joint stiffness. Intellectual disability, mucopolysacchariduria. Hurler Syndrome (MPS I-H) α -L-iduronidase Hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal deformities, cardiovascular complications; death by 6-10 years. Hunter Syndrome (MPS II) Iduronate-2-sulphatase. X-linked recessive; milder than Hurler, no corneal clouding. Gaucher Disease Glucocerebrosidase Glucocerebrosides. Type I: Non-neuronopathic; splenomegaly, skeletal issues, reduced lifespan. Type II: Acute neuronopathic; CNS involvement, early death. Type III: Intermediate; systemic and CNS involvement in adolescence/adulthood. Pompe Disease Acid alpha-glucosidase Glycogen in lysosomes Shares feature with LSDs despite classification as a glycogen storage disease. Cardiomegaly, muscle

questions.question: Sarah is a 3-year-old girl who is brought to her pediatrician by her parents due to concerns about her development. Her parents report that Sarah has been experiencing a loss of previously acquired skills, such as hand skills and language, stereotypic hand movements and seizure episodes . What is the mode of inheritance?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) X-linked dominant Explanation: The clinical manifestations in the patients point to Rett Syndrome. It has X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked dominant disorders are genetic conditions caused by mutations in genes located on the X chromosome. Unlike X-linked recessive disorders, which affect males more commonly due to having only one X chromosome, X-linked dominant disorders affect both males and females. All fathers that are affected by an X-linked dominant disorder will have affected daughters but not affected sons. However, if the mother is also affected then sons will have a chance of being affected, depending on whether a dominant or recessive X chromosome is passed on. When the son is affected, the mother will always be affected. Examples of X-linked dominant disorders ( Mnemonic : RAVI-C): R ett Syndrome A lport Syndrome (X-linked) V itamin D-dependent rickets I ncontinentia Pigmenti C harcot-Marie-Tooth disease Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 3193.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with severe hypotonia at birth, joint hypermobility, scoliosis, fragile skin, and ocular fragility. Genetic testing reveals mutations in the gene encoding Lysyl Hydroxylase. Which subtype of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is most likely present in this patient and its mode of inheritance.?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Kyphoscoliotic EDS - Autosomal Recessive Explanation: Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 150.

questions.question: What type of inheritance pattern is associated with hypertrichosis pinnae?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Holandric Explanation: Hypertrichosis, characterized by excessive hair growth on ears, is a rare genetic condition that can be associated with genes located on the Y chromosome. Since the Y chromosome is only present in males and is passed from fathers to sons, holandric traits are exclusively observed in males and are inherited from fathers. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 150.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive bleeding after a minor injury. His mother reports that his grandfather also had similar bleeding episodes. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in factor IX. What is the mode of inheritance for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) X-linked recessive Explanation: Factor IX deficiency, associated with Hemophilia B, is an X-linked recessive disorder that predominantly affects males, as evidenced by the family history. X-Linked Recessive : The gene for Hemophilia B is located on the X chromosome. Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation. Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X. Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers. X-linked Recessive (WISE ABCDEFGH) Wise- Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome AB- Hemophilia A, B B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia . C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness D- DMD, BMD E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome G- G6PD Deficiency H- Hunter Disease Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 146.

questions.question: If the mother and father have the β -thalassemia trait, what percentage of their children are expected to have β -thalassemia major?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 25% Explanation: There is a 25% chance that their child will inherit the genotype β I / β I , corresponding to β -thalassemia major . Mother's Genotype: β / β I (carrier for β -thalassemia) Father's Genotype: β / β I (carrier for β -thalassemia) Punnett Square Analysis: β β I β β / β β / β I β I β / β I β I / β I Possible Outcomes: β / β (Normal): 25% β / β I (Carrier): 50% β I / β I ( β -thalassemia major): 25% Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 145

questions.question: If a mother has sickle cell trait and the father has sickle cell disease , what percentage of their children are expected to have sickle cell disease?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 50% Explanation: There is a 50% chance that their child will inherit the genotype SS, which corresponds to sickle cell disease. Mother's Genotype: AS (carrier) Father's Genotype: SS (sickle cell disease) Punnett Square Analysis: S S A AS AS S SS SS Possible Outcomes: AS (Sickle cell trait): 50% SS (Sickle cell disease): 50% Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 145
